content:
The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" also amends income levels and sets a ceiling on investment insurance under the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The "Exports, Jobs, and Growth Act of 1996" increases the ceiling on investment insurance and financing, amends issuing authority, and provides policy guidance under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 104 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 by changing the year from 1996 to 2001. SEC. 105 provides policy guidance to increase US exports and complement trade policy. SEC. 106 establishes a Board of Directors. Section 233(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended by removing certain sentences and adding key officials to the list of individuals involved in the decision-making process. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include key officials in decision-making, such as the United States Trade Representative and a Deputy United States Trade Representative designated by the President. A Chairman and Vice Chairman of the Board will also be designated by the President from among the Directors of the Board. The President of the United States will designate key officials from the Board for specific roles under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade and Development Agency is authorized $40,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and additional funds as needed for fiscal year 1998. Export promotion programs within the International Trade Administration are also authorized. TITLE III--EXPORT PROMOTION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE INTERNATIONAL TRADE ADMINISTRATION

SEC. 301. EXPORT PROMOTION AUTHORIZATION.

Section 202 of the Export Administration Amendments Act of 1985 is amended to authorize appropriations of $240,000,000 for fiscal year 1997 and necessary sums for fiscal year 1998.

TITLE IV--TRADE PROMOTION COORDINATING COMMITTEE

SEC. 401. STRATEGIC EXPORT PLAN. Section 2312(c) of the Export Enhancement Act of 1988 is amended to include provisions for more coordinated export promotion services for small- and medium-sized businesses, as well as priorities for promoting US exports and free market reforms in the Middle East to stimulate job growth. SEC. 402. IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIMARY OBJECTIVES. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will identify and address overlap and duplication in Federal export promotion activities, promote better coordination between State, Federal, and private sector export promotion activities, and share market research data by September 30, 1997. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee aims to streamline federal export promotion activities, enhance coordination between state, federal, and private sector programs, and share market research data by September 30, 1997. These goals will be included in the annual report required under the Export Enhancement Act of 1988. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee will report on efforts to promote US trade and investment for private sector development in Ukraine in the 1997 annual report under the Export Enhancement Act of 1988.
